conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks a light source, and the outline of the shadow is a projection of the object's shape from the light source's position.
The size and shape of a shadow depend on the relative positions of the light source, the object, and the surface upon which the shadow is cast.
When the light source moves backward, it increases the distance between the light source and the objects, resulting in the shadows becoming smaller.
The direction of the light rays changes as the source moves backward, causing the shadows to shift closer to the objects.
Object A's shadow will become smaller and move closer to the base of the object.
Object B's shadow will become smaller and shift closer to the base of the object.
Object C's shadow will be smaller and move closer to the base.
Object D's shadow will reduce in size and move closer to the base of the object.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will all become smaller.
Shadows will shift closer to their respective objects.
When the light source moves backward above the objects, shadows A, B, C, and D will become smaller and move closer to the bases of their respective objects.
